unnormalised: So, someone asked about how academic results are viewed in India. It's a loaded question, tbh. In short, they matter. A lot. Maybe too much? Let me break it down, based on my experience and observations.
normalised: So, someone asked about how academic results are viewed in India. It's a loaded question, to be honest. In short, they matter. A lot. Maybe too much? Let me break it down, based on my experience and observations.

unnormalised: First off, marks in 10th and 12th (CBSE/ICSE/State boards, doesn't really matter which) are often seen as a make-or-break situation. Scoring above 90% opens doors to, like, all the "good" colleges. If you get, say, 60% in 10th, people will generally look down on you and you'll start hearing things like "isko toh kuch nahi aayega life mein" (this one won't amount to anything in life). Harsh, but true. Pressure cooker situation, especially for kids from middle-class families where education is seen as the golden ticket.
normalised: First off, marks in tenth and twelfth (C-B-S-E slash I-C-S-E slash State boards, doesn't really matter which) are often seen as a make-or-break situation. Scoring above ninety percent opens doors to, like, all the "good" colleges. If you get, say, sixty percent in tenth, people will generally look down on you and you'll start hearing things like "isko toh kuch nahi aayega life mein" (this one won't amount to anything in life). Harsh, but true. Pressure cooker situation, especially for kids from middle-class families where education is seen as the golden ticket.

unnormalised: Then comes the college entrance exams. JEE for engineering (aim for a rank under 10,000 to get into a decent IIT), NEET for medicine (600+ marks is the safe zone), and CLAT for law. These exams are a HUGE deal. People spend years preparing for them. Coaching centres like FIITJEE and Aakash are practically industries unto themselves. The cutoffs are crazy high, and just clearing the exam is often not enough. You need a good rank to get into a "good" college. My cousin scored 160/360 in JEE Main but it was enough to get him just a below average college.
normalised: Then comes the college entrance exams. J-E-E for engineering (aim for a rank under ten thousand to get into a decent I-I-T), N-E-E-T for medicine (six hundred plus marks is the safe zone), and C-L-A-T for law. These exams are a huge deal. People spend years preparing for them. Coaching centres like F-I-I-T-J-E-E and Aakash are practically industries unto themselves. The cutoffs are crazy high, and just clearing the exam is often not enough. You need a good rank to get into a "good" college. My cousin scored one hundred and sixty divided by three hundred and sixty in J-E-E Main but it was enough to get him just a below average college.

unnormalised: And then there's the whole grading system in college itself. Most Indian universities use a CGPA (Cumulative Grade Point Average) system, usually out of 10. Anything above 8 CGPA is considered good, 9+ is excellent. Some companies have a minimum CGPA requirement for internships and jobs (e.g., 7.5 CGPA or above). My friend at BITS Pilani was stressing because she got a 7.8 CGPA in her 2nd sem, saying she won't get any good internships. Overkill, I know.
normalised: And then there's the whole grading system in college itself. Most Indian universities use a C-G-P-A (Cumulative Grade Point Average) system, usually out of ten. Anything above eight C-G-P-A is considered good, nine plus is excellent. Some companies have a minimum C-G-P-A requirement for internships and jobs (for example, seven point five C-G-P-A or above). My friend at B-I-T-S Pilani was stressing because she got a seven point eight C-G-P-A in her second semester, saying she won't get any good internships. Overkill, I know.

unnormalised: Marks matter even after college. For masters programs abroad (like in the US or Europe), your undergraduate GPA is a critical factor. Also, competitive exams like GATE (for engineering) and CAT (for management) are super important for getting into top postgraduate programs in India (like IIMs). Again, it all boils down to marks/ranks. It’s a bit sad, but if you aren't scoring >98 percentile in CAT, you can't get a call from IIM Ahmedabad.
normalised: Marks matter even after college. For masters programs abroad (like in the U-S or Europe), your undergraduate G-P-A is a critical factor. Also, competitive exams like G-A-T-E (for engineering) and C-A-T (for management) are super important for getting into top postgraduate programs in India (like I-I-M-s). Again, it all boils down to marks slash ranks. It’s a bit sad, but if you aren't scoring greater than ninety eight percentile in C-A-T, you can't get a call from I-I-M Ahmedabad.

unnormalised: The emphasis on marks also leads to unhealthy competition and stress. Students often prioritize rote learning over understanding concepts. Parents put immense pressure on their kids. Suicide rates among students are sadly quite high in India, and the academic pressure plays a significant role.
normalised: The emphasis on marks also leads to unhealthy competition and stress. Students often prioritize rote learning over understanding concepts. Parents put immense pressure on their kids. Suicide rates among students are sadly quite high in India, and the academic pressure plays a significant role.

unnormalised: However, there's a growing awareness that marks aren't everything. Skills, creativity, and critical thinking are becoming increasingly valued. Startups and tech companies are often more interested in your skills and experience than your academic record. But old habits die hard, and the obsession with marks remains deeply ingrained in the Indian psyche. It will take a while to change that mindset.
normalised: However, there's a growing awareness that marks aren't everything. Skills, creativity, and critical thinking are becoming increasingly valued. Startups and tech companies are often more interested in your skills and experience than your academic record. But old habits die hard, and the obsession with marks remains deeply ingrained in the Indian psyche. It will take a while to change that mindset.

unnormalised: So, to sum it up, academic results are undeniably important in India. They open doors, create opportunities, and influence perceptions. But they're not the be-all and end-all. Skills, passion, and a bit of luck also play a significant role in shaping one's future.
normalised: So, to sum it up, academic results are undeniably important in India. They open doors, create opportunities, and influence perceptions. But they're not the be-all and end-all. Skills, passion, and a bit of luck also play a significant role in shaping one's future.
